issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

components.name: eucanetd
components.description: Used to track component level items associated with Edge.

fields.description:
In 4.1.0 with EDGE mode if a node controller machine is rebooted that has instances running on it, once the machine comes back up , eucanetd does not start properly. Instead it keep running in a *loop* trying to apply network isolation rules for instances that were running on this node controller prior to reboot.

This node controller, however can run new instances that comes and also eucanetd *appears* to have done the right thing with regards to the network rules for the new instances?

Tested by running new instances on the node controller and tried to ssh into them, that was successful. However until the instance is manually either removed from the CLC (euca-terminate-instances) or gets terminated after instance timeout? eucanetd keep doing the un-necessary thing for that instance.

Please let me know if there are any questions.

Cheers,
Deependra
fields.summary: eucanetd fails to apply network isolation rules

comments.body: [~dshekhawat] Does this cause any problems for instances that are currently running?

This does not seem to cause any problem so far from my testing. Only thing it did for me was kept populating the eucanetd log on the NC that got rebooted , for no reason. 

In an ideal world I would have expected the NC after it has come back online to send the real ground truth up to the CC and then CLC so it can do the right thing i.e. kill/terminate the instances running on the NC prior to reboot. 

This way CLC would also stop sending information about the instances running prior to reboot of the NC hence keeping eucanetd sane and not furiously populating the log file.

I will try to solve this in 4.2.0 if this is a problem. On reboot, EUCANETD will try to install rules for instance that were previously running IF the CLC propagate information about these instances in the global network view which is a behavior that would be expected. The node can run new instances because it tells CC that it has room and the CLC cannot make the difference. It is possible that this issue be a CLC issue and not a network issue if we don't like the CLC advertising instances that no longer exists.

I will try and reproduce and see where the actual issue is.
We don't want to pursue a redesign here. But perhaps there is a more graceful way to handle this condition.

As reported by [~tsugawa], this issue is already resolved in 4.2. If testing indicates otherwise please re-open. No commit was required as it was fixed during the eucanetd conversion work at the beginning of 4.2
